subject: RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 21st June 2019: Trump calls off Iran counter strike, reaches out for talks
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • SNAPSHOT: Equites down, Treasuries down, Dollar down, Crude up.
  • REAR VIEW: Trump calls off “disproportionate” counterstrike vs Iran; VP Pence calls off China speech, citing progress in talks; Clarida toes FOMC line; weak US PMIs, better EU PMIs.
  • NEXT WEEK: Sun: Turkish Election re-run; Mon: German Ifo Survey; Tues: Fed’s Powell, Williams, Hungarian Central Bank Monetary Policy meeting, US Consumer Confidence, New Home Sales, BCB Meeting minutes; Weds: RBNZ Monetary Policy meeting, US Durable Goods, BoE’s Carney; Thurs: Banxico Monetary Policy meeting, US GDP Final, EZ Sentiment; Fri; US Core PCE, Canada GDP. 
  • RANSQUAWK WEEK IN FOCUS - week commencing 24th June 2019. To download the report, please click here.

 

* IRAN: Tensions in the Persian Gulf were rife; overnight reports said President Trump had ordered and then consequentially cancelled an airstrike on Iran. Trump said he did not think it was worth killing 150 people for downing an autonomous drone, and instead sent a letter setting out a timetable for talks with Iran, which Supreme Leader Khamenei swiftly dismissed; however, separate reports suggested that US airstrikes were still on the cards. Iran took a similar tit-for-tat stance, saying that it would “respond to diplomacy with diplomacy and war with firm defence.” But Iran also laid some conditions it was after, such that if the US doesn’t want war it would have to ease sanctions. Some punchy comments out of the Iranian Revolutionary Guard did not express much diplomacy however, where it boasted that it could have shot down a manned US aircraft, in addition to the drone, as well as later saying that US bases and aircraft carriers are within the range of their missiles. Trump said he did not have any preconditions for talks, but the issues of ballistic missiles would have to be included and he would be open to meeting with Iranian officials such as President Rouhani. Close attention is to be payed on whether the two states can come together over the weekend, where if not, a military escalation seems likely according to some commentators, perhaps even Friday night, some have suggested.

* CHINA: US Vice President Mike Pence today opted to delay a China policy address, citing progress in talks between the two countries. Given Pence’s track record of delivering hawkish foreign policy speeches (such as last year when he laid out a number of grievances the Trump administration has with China related to human rights, religious freedom and intellectual property theft), this is likely to interpreted as a goodwill gesture; the equity markets certainly interpreted the comments in this way, rallying to fresh highs on the comments. China’s Global Times editor suggested that a significant hurdle for China in negotiations with the US is the issue of fairness, and alluded to that fact that China will not accept a deal if the US side does not remove all tariffs imposed since the onset of the trade war.

* FED: Fed’s Clarida (voter) toed the FOMC’s (now dovishly adopted) line, saying that there was broad agreement that the case for looser policy has increased, and that the Fed will act appropriately to sustain the expansion, that trends overseas might affect the US outlook. He did note that the US is close to its 2% inflation target. On Fed flexibility, Clarida said the bank had the room to act as needed, and rates were not, at present, close to the zero bound. When asked about the bank’s independence, he said it was not under threat. Fed's Bullard (voter, dove) revealed the reasons as to why he dissented at the Fed meeting on Wednesday; he argued that the factors behind weak inflation are unlikely to be solely transitory and pointed to market based inflation expectations; which have "weakened considerably" below the Fed's 2% target. Fed's Brainard (voter) said that risk management argues for a lower rate path when risks shift to the downside and she has seen downside risks in recent weeks. She said that rates will likely remain low in the future and that low inflation may create a self-fulfilling dynamic. She added that inflation indicators have been disappointing, making it important to sustain momentum, but caveated that the US economy remains solid. Fed's Kashkari (non-voter) said he called for a 50bps rate cut at this week's FOMC, arguing that aggressive action is needed to re-anchor inflation expectations, which he currently sees around 1.7%. He argued that Fed should commit to not raising rates until inflation is sustainably at 2.0%.

* ECB: ECB's Draghi reiterated his message from earlier in the week: telling EU leaders that signs of weakness are increasing, the economic rebound is weaker than expected and, in absence of a sustained return to the ECB's inflation target, additional stimulus will be required.

* US MARKIT FLASH PMI: Manufacturing PMI came in at 50.1 in June, down from 50.5 in May and below expectations for 50.4. This reading is the lowest since September 2009. Markit cited weaker rates of production growth and staff hiring as the key factors weighing on the headline, alongside the largest drop in stocks of purchases for almost a decade. Services PMI came in at 50.7, also below expectations (for 50.9) and pointed to the slowest growth in service output since 2016. Markit said “business activity edged closer to stagnation in June, expanding at the slowest rate since February 2016 and rounding off a second quarter in which the survey data point to the pace of economic expansion slipping to 1.4%”.

* US EXISTING HOME SALES: Rose to a three-month high in May at 5.34mln, beating the consensus for 5.3mln. "Sales continue their fitful recovery after last year's sharp decline, following the capping of state and local tax deductions from federal income tax," Pantheon Macroeconomics said. "Together with higher mortgage rates in the three quarters of the year, this depressed activity and slowed the rate of price increases." Sales are still running some way short of the pace implied by the path of mortgage applications, so Pantheon sees scope for further increases over the summer.

* CANADA RETAIL SALES: Retail Sales rose 0.1% in April, short of the 0.2% expected. The core rate at 0.1% was also short of the expected 0.3%. "Looking through monthly wiggles, sale volumes were still up 1.2% versus their Q1 average and 2.2% from a year ago," RBC writes, "That Y/Y rate is admittedly modest, but nonetheless the highest since September of last year." The bank notes that labour markets have remained very strong, and the unemployment rate hit another new cycle-low in May. "The pullback in interest rates in Canada and abroad in recent months mean that household debt payments won’t likely increase as much as has been previously feared this year or next." RBC is expecting consumer spending growth to remain relatively unimpressive. "The more pressing risk to the economic outlook at the moment, though, remains for a potential escalation in the US-China trade spat to generate more significant negative spillovers to the Canadian industrial sector," the bank warns.

* WTI FUTURES (Q9) SETTLE USD 0.36 HIGHER AT USD 57.43/BBL; BRENT FUTURES (Q9) SETTLES USD 0.75 HIGHER AT USD 65.20/BBL: Crude prices rose again to end the week, although more modestly when compared to Thursday, with the geopolitical risk premium and Fed induced risk appetite still providing tailwinds. Reports of Trump ordering and cancelling an airstrike on Iran, and Iran boasting that it could have shot down a manned US aircraft did nothing to calm the market’s fears of a military escalation. On a separate note, gasoline prices are likely to be having some supportive influence in the wider energy complex after the US East Coast’s largest refinery, the Philadelphia Energy Solutions refining complex, experienced some fire induced explosions, immediately cutting off 200k BPD of its 335k BPD capacity. US drillers adding rigs for the first week in three, where the latest Baker Hughes US rig count showed oil rigs +1 at 789, gas rigs -4 at 177, and total US rigs -2 at 967.

* US T-NOTE (U9) SETTLES 17+ LOWER AT 127-16+: Treasuries gave back some of the geopolitically induced gains seen on Thursday, with yields settling 5-7bps higher across the curve; this added some daylight between the 10-year yield and the 2% handle (which was breached on Thursday for the first time since Nov’2016). However, geopolitical analysts have warned that the tensions are far from over, and even though Trump has reached out to Iranian leaders for unconditional talks, military options remain. One macro desk noted that the 10-year yield is set to close higher for the seventh consecutive week, a rare event which last occurred in July 2016 (then finished sharply lower the next week, coinciding with Brexit events). Most of the run of today’s Fedspeak was an echo of the dovishness seen at the FOMC this week; the probability of a July rate cut has edged up to around 70% on Friday (from 60% a week ago), and money markets are pricing just shy of three rate cuts by the end of the year (CFTC data showed speculators adding long positions ahead of the Fed meeting). Next week’s sales of 2s, 5s and 7s will be eyed, with desks suggesting that the dovish Fed pricing could support the complex, like we saw in the 3s/10s/30s auctions recently, especially so amid the geopolitical background.

* S&P 500 -0.1% at 2951, NASDAQ-100 -0.1% at 7729, Dow Jones -0.1% at 26720, SECTORS: Consumer Discretionary -0.4%, Consumer Staples -0.4%, Energy 0.8%, Financials -0.3%, Health Care 0.5%, Industrials -0.5, Information Technology -0.5%, Materials -0.3%, Telecommunication Services 0.4%, Utilities 0.5%.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: CarMax (KMX) jumped higher after posting earnings that beat analyst expectations on both the top and bottom line. Laboratory Corp of America Holdings (LH) was upgraded at Deutsche Bank, which cited attractive valuations. PG&E (PCG) is mulling restructuring plan, which offered two-way volatility. Caterpillar (CAT) was under pressure, after a downgrade at Atlantic Equities, which is concerned about the global demand outlook. Apple (AAPL) was under pressure amid the iPhone maker recalling some of its MacBook Pro laptops in China. Micron Technologies (MU) fell after a number of brokers reduced their PTs for the chipmaker, citing concerns over the Huawei ban. Canopy Growth Corp (CGC) sunk after reporting bigger losses than expected, dragging stakeholder Constellation Brands (STZ) with it. PayPal (PYPL) fell after its COO resigned. Carnival Corp (CCL) fell, with Barclays downgrading the stock to underweight. The FTC has issued an objection to Qualcomm’s (QCOM) legal push to introduce internal Apple documents as evidence against the enforcement of the antitrust ruling made against the chipmaker in May. Tesla (TSLA) was also under pressure after a source suggested that Q2 optimism on deliveries may be overdone. Energy names performed well as crude prices remained elevated, as did gold names as Gold reclaimed the USD 1400 handle. 

* FX WRAP: The USD decline continued on Friday after a slate of dovish Fed-speak and another batch of weak PMI survey data, despite rising geopolitical tensions in the Middle East which have often benefited the dollar. EUR was the big beneficiary of a weaker buck, EURUSD reaching 3-month highs at 1.1370, also getting a push from strong German and French Markit PMI data, which offer nascent signs of green shoots. Despite heavy geopolitical news flow, JPY is slightly softer against the buck on Friday, but remains around the 107.50 mark after this week’s dovish Fed/BoJ and rising tensions in the Middle East; weakness was attributed to MOF comments overnight, after it signalled a willingness to act on concerns about yen strength. Likewise, Gold also holds onto recent gains, but is finding the air above 1400 to be slightly thin. All quiet on the Brexit/Conservative leadership contest front; GBP traded as a function of dollar weakness, with GBPUSD moving back above 1.2700, while EURGBP was a function of EUR strength. CAD was weaker, after retail sales slightly disappointed, but holds onto recent gains vs the buck around 1.3200. EMFX was mixed; BRL a touch stronger as recent optimism on pension reform continues but MXN was weaker, moving back above the 19.10 handle. RUB saw momentary downside on the news Democrats were mulling a fresh round of sanctions, but was ultimately underpinned by the weaker buck and rising crude prices. Weekly FX Wrap: dovish thread runs from RBA through ECB, Fed and BoE, but knot Norges Bank
content:
DXY

The Dollar is probing fresh weekly lows in wake of weaker than forecast US Markit PMIs and a whisker shy of post-NFP levels in index terms, as the bleak surveys provide more justification for the FOMC’s shift in policy stance from patience to ready to respond appropriately. To recap, nigh on half the voting members changed their dot plots to include pre-year end easing from no move previously, and Fed Chair Powell revealed in the post-meeting press conference that even those sticking to their March convictions did concede that the case for more stimulus is now stronger. The very dovish hold and new guidance (with Bullard dissenting in favour of a 25 bp cut) more than matched already hyped up market expectations as the probability of a July move tops 100%. In fact, the chances of a ½ point reduction is now approaching 25% and 100 bp worth of easing is being priced in for the next cycle. Back to the DXY, better than expected existing home sales data appears to have stopped the rot as the index recovers from 96.455 and back over 96.500, though still well off highs (97.770) set just ahead of the FOMC and largely at the expense of the Euro.

EUR

Friday’s G10 outperformer, and in stark contrast to the Greenback, setting new peaks for the week around 1.1335 compared to 1.1182 at the other extreme, with encouragement drawn from encouraging French and German preliminary PMIs. However, the single currency remains much closer to the base of 1.1220-1.1055 trading parameters vs the CHF after another seminal Sintra moment from ECB President Draghi who acknowledged heightened risks of inflation not sustaining a path towards target and indicators showing a more pronounced/prolonged downturn in growth that in turn threatens price stability and the de-anchoring of expectations.

AUD/GBP/NOK

As noted above, also subject to Central Bank impulses, but to varying and contrasting degrees, as RBA minutes and Governor Lowe underlined the rational for more easing, while the ranks of banks predicting a 0.5% OCR either by the end of 2019 or pre-H2 next year rose further. Hence, the Aussie is still struggling to build on recovery gains above 0.6900 vs its US peer, albeit unwinding losses from 0.6832 at one stage and also ending the week more resiliently than its Antipodean counterpart as Aud/NZD reclaims 1.0500+ status within a 1.0590-1.0480 band and the Kiwi slips back from 0.6600 against the Usd towards 0.6550. Note, the RBNZ meets next week and could continue to largely more dovish trend, but may refrain given solid Q1 NZ GDP – see our Research Suite for a full preview. Meanwhile, Pound has been volatile across the board as Tory voting and TV debates continue and Brexiteer Boris Johnson strengthened his position as favourite to replace May as leader and PM (race down to 2, with Hunt far behind). However, Cable is back near best levels within a 1.2727-1.2507 range and Eur/Gbp midway between 0.8975-0.8875 after the BoE maintained a gradual and limited tightening bias, but was not hawkish as some anticipated. Conversely, the Norges Bank hiked rates as promised, and then went further with a slightly more aggressive rate path than previously by signalling 2 more 25 bp rises before summer 2020. Governor Olsen subsequently indicated that the next likely move would be in September.

JPY

Broad risk sentiment, US Treasury vs JGB yields in a mainly bull market and some large option expiries drove the Yen more than a still powerfully accommodative BoJ that reaffirmed a willingness to provide more stimulus. Usd/Jpy veered between 107.06-108.72 lines and ruffled the feathers of Japanese authorities when close to the base.

EM

Another big week for several regional currencies in terms of moves, events and news as the Rand weathered some negative headlines from Fitch, but derived support from SA President Ramaphosa’s pledge to offer more financial help to Eskom. Meanwhile, the Lira and Rouble were both wary about deeper US sanctions against Turkey and Russia, while the former is also conscious that the Istanbul rerun looms and the 2 main parties are set for another hotly contested and disputed election battle. On the flip-side, the Real gleaned momentum from apparent progress on the Brazilian Pension Reform Bill front.

Nomura Quant: A global equity dip ahead of the G20 could present a buying opportunity
content:
• Judging from the pattern of market sentiment and supply-demand among hedge funds, Nomura still expect the risk rally in equities to sustain into July
  • During the last peak, stock market gains continued for about a month after sentiment peaked and began falling. Therefore, any dip in share prices ahead of the G20 meeting may represent a good opportunity to buy as gains
  • Hedge funds typically have only limited exposure to equities, therefore there is scope for funds to lift their equity exposure if the risk rally gains momentum
  • CTAs are still steadily adding to their long position in US equity futures; their net long position in S&P 500 futures is now back up to 37% of the peak level marked just ahead of the May selloff
  • Overall, long/short funds are reducing their long exposure to defensives and gradually adding to their long exposure to cyclicals

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Equity Opening News - 21st June 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

DOW

  • Apple (AAPL) (Information Technology/Technology Hardware, Storage & Peripherals) is to recall some of its 15-inch MacBook Pro laptops sold in the Chinese market due to battery overheating that may pose fire hazards; around 63,000 batteries were estimated to have the problem on the Chinese mainland reported Xinhua.
  • Caterpillar (CAT) (Industrials/Construction Machinery & Heavy Trucks) was downgraded to underweight from neutral at Atlantic Equities, who cited expectations of weaker global economic growth.
  • Chevron (CVX) (Energy/Integrated Oil & Gas), Phillips 66 (PSX) (Energy/Oil & Gas Refining & Marketing) - Chevron Phillips Chemical Company, a joint venture between Chevron and Phillips 66, has offered to acquire Nova Chemicals for at least USD 15bln (including debt). However, sources suggest that there is no guarantee that Nova Chemical’s owner, Mubadala Investment will accept the offer and other bidders may emerge.
  • Exxon Mobil Corp (XOM) (Energy/Integrated Oil & Gas) is reportedly holding back on a previously planned USD 53bln investment to boost Iraqi oil output, amid geopolitical tensions in the region, according to Iraqi government officials.
  • McDonalds (MCD) (Consumer Discretionary/Restaurants) is reportedly testing voice-recognition software at its drive-throughs and robotic deep-fryers as the fast food maker looks to speed up service.
  • Merck (MRK) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) had its price target raised to USD 95 from USD 84 at Citi, whose analysts suggested that the company's intensified cost focus should offset the anticipated impact of increased competition for its headline Keytruda cancer treatment, especially outside the U.S.
  • United Health Corp (UNH) (Health Care/Managed Health Care) is set to acquire health-care payments company Equian LLC for roughly USD 3.2bln, the WSJ reported. There is speculation that UnitedHealth will merge Equian into its own Optum health-services arm, helping it to branch out into areas beyond health care.

NASDAQ 100

  • Alphabet (GOOG, GOOGL) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) has aborted plans to make its own tablet devices and will not release a successor for the Pixelbook Slate. Separately, the WSJ reported that Google Maps is filled with millions of false business addresses and fake names causing users to be lured into potentially expensive or even risky situations. Google issued a response to the article; in which it detailed the measures it takes to combat the problem.
  • Facebook (FB) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) announced a new Strategic Response team, which will be tasked with quickly reacting to geopolitical events. Elsewhere, Facebook co-founder Chris Hughes said that a Libra coin would shift power into the wrong hands, and that regulators should not underestimate the digital currency's disruptive potential, reported the FT. "If global regulators don't act now, it could very soon be too late," he said.
  • Micron Technologies (MU) (Information Technology/Semiconductors) has had its price target lowered to USD 28 from USD 32 at Baird, whilst they kept their Underperform rating for the stock. Baird analysts note that DRAM and NAND inventories have deteriorated quarter-over-quarter and are now about twice the normal levels in the supply chain. JP Morgan also lowered their price target for the co., who’s reduced estimates reflect the component bans to Huawei, which was 13% of its customer base in H1 2019.
  • PayPal (PYPL) (Information Technology/Data Processing & Outsourced Services) announced that COO Ready will leave at the end of 2019, to pursue opportunities outside of the company.
  • Qualcomm (QCOM) (Information Technology/Semiconductors) – The US FTC has issued an objection Qualcomm’s (QCOM) legal push to introduce internal Apple (AAPL) documents as evidence against the enforcement of the antitrust ruling made against the chipmaker in May.
  • Regeneron (REGN) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) and Sanofi (SAN FP) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) have announced positive top-line Phase II results for IL-33 antibody in Asthma. (Newswires)
  • Tesla (TSLA) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobile Manufacturers) has had its price target boosted at Baird to USD 355 from USD 340, who also reiterated an Outperform rating for the shares. Analysts suggest that consensus expectations for deliveries "have overshot to the negative," creating a favourable share setup for the remainder of the year. Analysts expect Q2 delivery numbers by 3 July and stock price to react positively.

S&P 500

  • Allergan (AGN) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) – The FDA has approved the use of BOTOX for paediatric patients with upper limb spasticity, whilst the FDA is also reviewing the use of BOTOX to treat lower limb spasticity with the decision expected in Q4 of this year.
  • Carmax (KMX) (Consumer Discretionary/Specialty Stores) (USD) report Q1 EPS 1.59 (exp. 1.49), revenue 5.37bln (exp. 5.18), unit sales in comparable stores increased 9.5%, total used unit sales rose 13.0%, total wholesale unit sales increased 6.6%.
  • Constellation Brands (STZ) (Consumer Staples/Distillers & Vintners) have realised USD 38mln in losses from its equity method investment in Canopy Growth Corp (CGC), who reported larger than expected losses last night.
  • Delta Airlines (DAL) (Industrials/Airlines) has acquired a 4.3% stake in Hanjin Kal, which is the parent company of Korean Airlines, and says it wants to raise it to 10% after Delta and Korean Airlines formed a joint venture last year.
  • Medtronic (MDT) (Health Care/Health Care Equipment) raised its quarterly dividend to USD 0.54 per share from USD 0.50.
  • Norwegian Cruise Line Holding’s (NCLH) (Consumer Discretionary/Hotels, Resorts & Cruise Lines) pullback on Carnival earnings could be a buying opportunity, according to Stifel. Having recently spent time with the management team, Stifel analysts remains confident in their ability to deliver on the objectives laid out at their 2018 analyst day.
  • Red Hat (RHT) (Information Technology/Systems Software) (USD) Q1 19 EPS 1.00 (exp. 0.86), revenue 0.93bln (exp. 0.93bln), reports Q1 subscription revenue 0.815bln, up 15% from last year. William Blair analysts downgraded the co. to Market Perform from Outperform, citing the approaching takeover by IBM (IBM).
  • United Continental Airlines (UAL) (Industrials/Airlines) has suspended flights to Mumbai from Newark following a safety review after recent escalations in tensions between the US and Iran.

OTHER

  • Dell Technologies (DELL) (Information Technology/Technology Hardware, Storage & Peripherals) – Safebreach has identified a major security vulnerability that could potentially affect several million laptops. The vulnerability was discovered in late May, Dell has since implemented a fix and released updates.
  • Energy Transfer’s (ET) (Energy/Oil, Gas & Consumable Fuels) Philadelphia Energy refinery, 335k BPD refinery, experienced a fire on Friday morning, with explosions also reported.
  • IQE plc (IQE LN) is the latest Huawei supplier to slash guidance. Given commentary, this may reach a touch further than Huawei: Larger impact than the previously guided risk related specifically to Huawei, due to “the far-reaching impacts” on other companies and supply chains that are now becoming evident.

subject: Fixed and FX latest: bonds still bearish or less wanted, and Loonie likewise
content: Not much additional movement since US participants re-joined the fray, as debt markets continue to consolidate or take a breather after this week’s heady rally on a mixture of dovish Central Bank policy developments and deteriorating diplomatic/geopolitical situation. However, in the absence of any early US data, softer than forecast Canadian retail sales did spark some price action in Usd/Cad and a knee-jerk over 1.3200 before upward revisions to the previous month and ongoing Greenback weakness capped the initial move.

RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 21st June 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • European stocks gave up earlier gains on quadruple witching day, sectors are mostly in the red
  • Dollar trades within a tight range above 95.50, EUR is supported by encouraging EZ PMIs
  • US President Trump reportedly pulled back from launching attacks on Iran hours after approving strikes on a handful of targets
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US PMIs, Canadian retail sales, Baker Hughes, Fed’s Mester, Daly, BoE’s Tenreyro and Carney, quadruple witching

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets traded mostly lacklustre as the FOMC-fuelled momentum began to wane in the region despite the strong lead from Wall St where the S&P 500 rallied to fresh all-time highs and the energy sector outperformed on further oil advances. ASX 200 (-0.6% ) and Nikkei 225 (-1.0%) were both lower although downside was stemmed for most the session by strength in energy and commodity-related stocks after WTI gained around 6% and gold broke above USD 1400/oz for the first time since September 2013, while South32 was among the notable gainers in Australia after it received a couple of bids for its coal assets. Chinese markets were mixed with the Hang Seng (-0.3%) subdued after further disruptions from protesters discontent the extradition law wasn’t fully withdrawn by their set deadline and who also demanded that all charges against those involved in last week’s protests are dropped. Conversely, the Shanghai Comp. (+0.5%) bucked the trend and rose above the 3,000 level after the PBoC’s liquidity efforts resulted to a net injection of CNY 285bln for the week and with US-China trade negotiating teams said to meet as early as Tuesday. Finally, 10yr JGBs were higher and briefly broke above 154.00 amid the subdued risk tone in Japan and BoJ presence in the market for JPY 1.23tln of JGBs in 1yr-10yr maturities, while yields continued to decline in which Japanese 10yr yields fell to the lowest since July 2016.

PBoC injected CNY 30bln via 14-day reverse repos for a weekly net injection of CNY 285bln vs. Prev. CNY 65bln. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8472 (Prev. 6.8805) – Strongest fix since February 21st

US and China negotiating teams could meet as soon as Tuesday. (SCMP)

China Banking and Insurance Regulatory Commission said the effect of US tariffs on China's economy will be very limited, while there were separate reports from Global Times that China urged the US to halt the abuse of state power to suppress Chinese companies. (Newswires/Global Times) 

Japanese National CPI (May) Y/Y 0.7% vs. Exp. 0.7% (Prev. 0.9%) Japanese National CPI Ex. Fresh Food (May) Y/Y 0.8% vs. Exp. 0.8% (Prev. 0.9%) Japanese National CPI Ex. Fresh Food & Energy (May) Y/Y 0.5% vs. Exp. 0.5% (Prev. 0.6%) 

US

US President Trump and Canadian PM Trudeau instructed officials to develop a joint action plan for collaborating on critical minerals. (Newswires)

CENTRAL BANKS

Fed's Clarida (Voter) said the Fed will act appropriately to sustain the expansion; the US is close to its 2% inflation target; trends overseas might affect the US outlook, adding that the borad agreement is that the case for looser Fed policy has increased. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

US President Trump reportedly pulled back from launching attacks on Iran hours after approving strikes on a handful of targets including radar and missile batteries, while an official noted that planes were in the air and ships were in position but no missiles had been fired when the word came to stand down. Furthermore, US President Trump delivered Iran a message via Oman, warning of an imminent attack, with the message also noting "we do not want war but talks" and gave Tehran a deadline to start discussions, according to officials. (Newswires) 

Several top US House Republicans said there must be a measured response to Iran actions, although there were separate comments from US House Speaker Pelosi that the US needs to do everything in its power to de-escalate situation with Iran. (Newswires)

US FAA issues emergency order prohibiting all US flights in overwater area of Iran-controlled airspace above Persian Gulf and Gulf of Oman. (Newswires)

EU Commission President Juncker commented that what Turkey is doing in territorial waters of Cyprus is unacceptable and that proposals against Turkey over the drilling will not be soft. (Newswires)

UK/EU

EU Council President Tusk said there was no majority for any candidate for any of the EU's top jobs and EU's Juncker commented that he doesn’t expect it will be easy to reach deal regarding the top jobs, while EU leaders agreed to conduct another summit on assigning the bloc's top positions on June 30th. (Newswires)

Italian Deputy PM Salvini says he is ready to quit if the government cannot cut taxes for EUR 10bln, according to Corriere Della Sera. (Newswires)

EU Markit Manufacturing Flash PMI (Jun) 47.8 vs. Exp. 48.0 (Prev. 47.7) (Newswires) - Services Flash PMI (Jun) 53.4 vs. Exp. 52.9 (Prev. 52.9) - Composite Flash PMI (Jun) 52.1 vs. Exp. 51.8 (Prev. 51.8)

EQUITIES

European equities are mixed [Eurostoxx 50 Unch] as the region received a lacklustre handover from Asia on quadruple witching day. The European cash open was relatively uninspiring with most bourses flat/lower before receiving some impetus from encouraging French and German flash PMIs, albeit the EZ metrics were mixed. Sectors are now mostly in the red but energy names lead the gains amid the this week’s price action in the complex. In terms of individual movers, Natixis (-4.0%) shares fell amid a downgrade at HSBC. On the flip side, Elior (+4.3%) shares are bolstered due to a positive broker move at Goldman Sachs. Elsewhere, Telecom Italia (+1.6%) shares rose amid reports that the Co. signed a non-disclosure agreement to start talks regarding a TIM and Open Fiber network integration. Finally, looking at analysis from Nomura Quant, the bank believes that dips in stocks ahead of G20 pose good buying opportunities as it sees signs of increased equity exposures by speculators , “Judging from the pattern of market sentiment and supply-demand among hedge funds, we still expect the risk rally to sustain into July”, Nomura says.

FX

EUR - The single currency has gleaned support from above forecast French and German preliminary PMIs that appear to have offset weakness elsewhere in the Eurozone and underpinned the pan prints to an extent. However, Eur/Usd has stalled well ahead of major resistance in the 1.1347-50 area where 200 WMA and DMAs reside as the Greenback attempts to stabilise following its Fed induced sell-off and the DXY holds just above 96.500 vs 96.492 lows. Note also, hefty 2.5 bn option expiry interest at the 1.1300 strike is keeping the headline pair contained, while Eur/CHF remains top heavy and technically bearish around 1.1100 even though the Franc is fading vs the Buck within a 0.9808-38 range.

CAD/SEK - Also relative G10 outperformers as the Loonie holds above 1.3200 against its US counterpart and looks towards Canadian retail sales data for more independent direction, while the Swedish Krona seems to be benefiting from Scandi cross flows as its Norwegian peer loses some Norges Bank momentum, with Eur/Sek hovering just above 10.6100 and Eur/Nok rebounding from the low 9.6500 region to 9.6850+ at one stage.

NZD/AUD/GBP/JPY - All weaker vs the recovering Usd, as the Kiwi fails to sustain gains above 0.6600 and Aussie wanes ahead of 0.6950 alongside a pull-back in the Yuan after a strong PBoC midpoint fix overnight. Meanwhile, Cable has been unable to retain grip of the 1.2700 handle yet again after topping out close to yesterday’s 1.2727 high for the week so far and the Yen has pulled up short of 107.00 with decent expiries between the figure and 107.05 (1.4 bn) adding to psychological resistance, as Japan’s monetary authorities monitor currency moves closely. On the flip-side, 1.3 bn options at 107.50 and a further 2.8 bn from 107.70-80 may well keep Usd/Jpy in check into the NY cut, if not beyond.

EM - Widespread declines as the Dollar regains a degree of composure, and with the Lira also wary about the weekend election rerun in Istanbul following all the rumpus after the first vote. Usd/Try is back over 5.8000, while the Rand and Rouble are also handing back a chunk of their recent gains but not quite to the same extent, with Usd/Zar and Usd/Rub straddling 14.4100 and 63.1000 respectively. Note, MS has reportedly shorted the latter pair at 63.3000, looking for 60.0000 and placing a stop at 65.0000.mitigation.

FIXED INCOME

Bunds and Gilts have staged relatively decent recoveries from post-Eurozone PMI lows that were exacerbated by technical and stop-selling once near term chart supports and recent lows gave way. The 10 year EU benchmarks are currently around 172.26 and 130.39 vs 171.95 and 130.13 Eurex and Liffe lows as equities retreat amidst ongoing US-Iran accusations and counterclaims over the downed drone and following what appears to have been a last minute decision by the White House to refrain from physical retaliation. Meanwhile, Italian bonds have bounced even more impressively after the BTP swap, but US Treasuries are still hemmed near overnight session lows and the curve is steeper ahead of Markit PMIs, existing home sales and more Fed speakers following lone rate cut dissenter Bullard.

German Debt Agency has lowered its Q3 issuance by EUR 2bln; total now seen at EUR 197bln. (Newswires)

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent futures continue to advance as tensions in the Middle East escalate, with NYT reporting that the Trump administration considered a strike in Iran following the downing of the US spy drone yesterday. Furthermore, officials stated that US President Trump delivered Iran a warning of an imminent attack, with the message noting "we do not want war but talks" and gave Tehran a deadline to start discussions. Brent is poised for it biggest weekly gain since April and inches closer to the USD 65/bbl level ahead of its 100 WMA at 67.10. Meanwhile, WTI  futures reclaimed the USD 57.00/bbl handle before hitting resistance close to USD 58.00/bbl. ING believes “oil prices  will trend higher over the second half of the year” due to the flaring tensions in the Middle East, coupled with expectations for an OPEC+ extension. Elsewhere, gold topped USD 1400/oz in Asia trade (albeit now back below the figure) and reached a high of USD 1411/oz, levels last seen in September 2013. Upside in the yellow metal has been driven primarily by the dovish tilts in major central banks, a weakening Buck and fears of potential war between the US and Iran. Gold remains near to the top of this week’s 1333-1411 range thus far. Elsewhere, copper pared some of yesterday’s gains as the FOMC-led momentum waned overnight, although the red metal is off lows. Finally, Dalian iron ore futures continued to advance as concerns persisted over tight supply, strong demand and declining shipments from Rio Tinto.

A fire has been reported at Philadelphia Energy refinery [332k-335k BPD], according to the fire department, the largest refinering on the East Coast. (Newswires)

Japanese Petroleum Association are studying possibles measure for potential supply disruptions from the Middle East including use of reserves and buying oil from Western Africa or US. (Newswires)

subject: German Chancellor Merkel says the Withdrawal Agreement is final

Fed's Clarida (voter) says broad agreement that the case for looser policy has increased; will act appropriately to sustain the expansion; the US is close to its 2% inflation target; trends overseas might affect the US outlook
content:
• Fed has the flexibility to act as needed as rates are not close to the zero bound
  • Fed's independence is not under threat

ING believes “oil prices  will trend higher over the second half of the year” due to the flaring tensions in the Middle East, coupled with expectations for an OPEC+ extension. Elsewhere, gold topped USD 1400/oz in Asia trade (albeit now back below the figure) and reached a high of USD 1411/oz, levels last seen in September 2013. Upside in the yellow metal has been driven primarily by the dovish tilts in major central banks, a weakening Buck and fears of potential war between the US and Iran. Gold remains near to the top of this week’s 1333-1411 range thus far. Elsewhere, copper pared some of yesterday’s gains as the FOMC-led momentum waned overnight, although the red metal is off lows. Finally, Dalian iron ore futures continued to advance as concerns persisted over tight supply, strong demand and declining shipments from Rio Tinto.

content: Bunds and Gilts have staged relatively decent recoveries from post-Eurozone PMI lows that were exacerbated by technical and stop-selling once near term chart supports and recent lows gave way. The 10 year EU benchmarks are currently around 172.26 and 130.39 vs 171.95 and 130.13 Eurex and Liffe lows as equities retreat amidst ongoing US-Iran accusations and counterclaims over the downed drone and following what appears to have been a last minute decision by the White House to refrain from physical retaliation. Meanwhile, Italian bonds have bounced even more impressively after the BTP swap, but US Treasuries are still hemmed near overnight session lows and the curve is steeper ahead of Markit PMIs, existing home sales and more Fed speakers following lone rate cut dissenter Bullard.

subject: Fed's Bullard (Voter, Dove) dissented at the Fed meeting as he feels the factors behind weak inflation are unlikely to be solely transitory
content: • Market based inflation expectations have "weakened considerably" below the Fed's 2% target

subject: FX Morning Colour: perkier PMIs prop up Euro, as Dollar pares some post-FOMC losses
content:
EUR

The single currency has gleaned support from above forecast French and German preliminary PMIs that appear to have offset weakness elsewhere in the Eurozone and underpinned the pan prints to an extent. However, Eur/Usd has stalled well ahead of major resistance in the 1.1347-50 area where 200 WMA and DMAs reside as the Greenback attempts to stabilise following its Fed induced sell-off and the DXY holds just above 96.500 vs 96.492 lows. Note also, hefty 2.5 bn option expiry interest at the 1.1300 strike is keeping the headline pair contained, while Eur/CHF remains top heavy and technically bearish around 1.1100 even though the Franc is fading vs the Buck within a 0.9808-38 range.

CAD/SEK

Also relative G10 outperformers as the Loonie holds above 1.3200 against its US counterpart and looks towards Canadian retail sales data for more independent direction, while the Swedish Krona seems to be benefiting from Scandi cross flows as its Norwegian peer loses some Norges Bank momentum, with Eur/Sek hovering just above 10.6100 and Eur/Nok rebounding from the low 9.6500 region to 9.6850+ at one stage.

NZD/AUD/GBP/JPY

All weaker vs the recovering Usd, as the Kiwi fails to sustain gains above 0.6600 and Aussie wanes ahead of 0.6950 alongside a pull-back in the Yuan after a strong PBoC midpoint fix overnight. Meanwhile, Cable has been unable to retain grip of the 1.2700 handle yet again after topping out close to yesterday’s 1.2727 high for the week so far and the Yen has pulled up short of 107.00 with decent expiries between the figure and 107.05 (1.4 bn) adding to psychological resistance, as Japan’s monetary authorities monitor currency moves closely. On the flip-side, 1.3 bn options at 107.50 and a further 2.8 bn from 107.70-80 may well keep Usd/Jpy in check into the NY cut, if not beyond.

EM

Widespread declines as the Dollar regains a degree of composure, and with the Lira also wary about the weekend election rerun in Istanbul following all the rumpus after the first vote. Usd/Try is back over 5.8000, while the Rand and Rouble are also handing back a chunk of their recent gains but not quite to the same extent, with Usd/Zar and Usd/Rub straddling 14.4100 and 63.1000 respectively. Note, MS has reportedly shorted the latter pair at 63.3000, looking for 60.0000 and placing a stop at 65.0000.

subject: US President Trump delivered Iran a message via Oman, warning of an imminent attack, with the message also noting "we do not want war but talks" and gave Tehran a deadline to start discussions, according to officials
content:
• In response, officials suggested Supreme Leader Khamenei was opposed to 'any kind of talks with the US' but was given the message.
  • Tehran warned over potential 'regional and international' consequences of any US military action.
analysis_details:
• This comes after NYT noted that US President Trump reportedly pulled back from launching attacks on Iran hours after approving strikes on a handful of targets including radar and missile batteries, while an official noted that planes were in the air and ships were in position but no missiles had been fired when the word came to stand down.
  • Furthermore, US President Trump answered "you'll soon find out" when asked if the US will strike Iran. However, President Trump later added that he does not feel like his administration is pushing him toward conflict and in some cases it’s the opposite, while he suggested the drone shooter could have been someone who was "loose and stupid".

UK debt and STIR futures retreat further from midweek peaks
content: Gilts gapped down on their return to Liffe and following a fleeting attempt to pare some losses have subsequently reversed deeper into negative alongside Bunds and US Treasuries as firmer than forecast French PMIs are supplemented by Germany beating consensus, albeit not to the same extent and the manufacturing sector still far from returning to expansion. The 10 year debt future has breached Thursday’s session low (130.30) and is edging towards the next chart support level ahead of 130.00 around 130.08, with the base so far at 130.18 (-52 ticks on the day), as its German peer eyes 172.00 from a 172.03 trough. Back to Liffe, Short Sterling contracts are as much as 4 ticks adrift in advance of UK public finance data and a scheduled speech by BoE’s Tenreyro from 13.30BST. For the record, nothing new on policy when Governor Carney was interviewed on BBC radio 4 earlier.

subject: Bunds: primed for flash Eurozone PMIs and looking for some stability at least
content: The 10 year German benchmark continues to consolidate below Tuesday’s contract highs having fallen just shy of the 172.88 peak on renewed buying spurred by the Fed and a ramp up in geopolitically motivated demand for safe havens. However, while bullish momentum appears to be waning pull-backs remain shallow given heightened prospects that the ECB and FOMC are poised to join other global Central Banks on an easier policy footing. Bunds are just probing fresh 172.44 Eurex lows after opening at 172.55 vs yesterday’s 172.64 close and briefly edging above parity to 172.65 before fading again, while EU stocks have kicked off rather indifferently ahead of preliminary PMIs and BTPs are paring some losses in the run-up to Italy’s exchange auction.

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded mostly lacklustre as the FOMC-fuelled momentum began to wane in the region despite the strong lead from Wall St where the S&P 500 rallied to fresh all-time highs and the energy sector outperformed on further oil advances. ASX 200 (-0.6%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.9%) were both lower although downside was stemmed for most the session by strength in energy and commodity-related stocks after WTI gained around 6% and gold broke above USD 1400/oz for the first time since September 2013, while South32 was among the notable gainers in Australia after it received a couple of bids for its coal assets. Chinese markets were mixed with the Hang Seng (-0.2%) subdued after further disruptions from protesters discontent the extradition law wasn’t fully withdrawn by their set deadline and who also demanded that all charges against those involved in last week’s protests are dropped. RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 21st June 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Asian equity markets traded mostly lacklustre as the FOMC-fuelled momentum began to wane in the region despite the strong lead from Wall St
  • Boris Johnson maintained the lead after the 5th round of the Tory leadership ballot with Jeremy Hunt making it to the final two after Michael Gove was eliminated
  • US President Trump reportedly pulled back from launching attacks on Iran hours after approving strikes on a handful of targets
  • Looking ahead, highlights include Eurozone and US PMIs, Canadian retail sales, Baker Hughes, Fed’s Rosengren, Clarida, Mester, Daly, BoE’s Tenreyro and Carney, quadruple witching

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets traded mostly lacklustre as the FOMC-fuelled momentum began to wane in the region despite the strong lead from Wall St where the S&P 500 rallied to fresh all-time highs and the energy sector outperformed on further oil advances. ASX 200 (-0.6%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.9%) were both lower although downside was stemmed for most the session by strength in energy and commodity-related stocks after WTI gained around 6% and gold broke above USD 1400/oz for the first time since September 2013, while South32 was among the notable gainers in Australia after it received a couple of bids for its coal assets. Chinese markets were mixed with the Hang Seng (-0.2%) subdued after further disruptions from protesters discontent the extradition law wasn’t fully withdrawn by their set deadline and who also demanded that all charges against those involved in last week’s protests are dropped. Conversely, the Shanghai Comp. (+0.6%) bucked the trend and rose above the 3,000 level after the PBoC’s liquidity efforts resulted to a net injection of CNY 285bln for the week and with US-China trade negotiating teams said to meet as early as Tuesday. Finally, 10yr JGBs were higher and briefly broke above 154.00 amid the subdued risk tone in Japan and BoJ presence in the market for JPY 1.23tln of JGBs in 1yr-10yr maturities, while yields continued to decline in which Japanese 10yr yields fell to the lowest since July 2016.

PBoC injected CNY 30bln via 14-day reverse repos for a weekly net injection of CNY 285bln vs. Prev. CNY 65bln. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8472 (Prev. 6.8805)

US and China negotiating teams could meet as soon as Tuesday. (SCMP)

China Banking and Insurance Regulatory Commission said the effect of US tariffs on China's economy will be very limited, while there were separate reports from Global Times that China urged the US to halt the abuse of state power to suppress Chinese companies. (Newswires/Global Times) 

Japanese National CPI (May) Y/Y 0.7% vs. Exp. 0.7% (Prev. 0.9%) Japanese National CPI Ex. Fresh Food (May) Y/Y 0.8% vs. Exp. 0.8% (Prev. 0.9%) Japanese National CPI Ex. Fresh Food & Energy (May) Y/Y 0.5% vs. Exp. 0.5% (Prev. 0.6%) 

UK/EU

Boris Johnson maintained the lead after the 5th round of the Tory leadership ballot with 160 votes, while Jeremy Hunt received 77 votes and Michael Gove was eliminated with 75 votes, which sets up a runoff between Johnson and Hunt. (Newswires)

EU's Tusk said there was no majority for any candidate for any of the EU's top jobs and EU's Juncker commented that he doesn’t expect it will be easy to reach deal regarding the top jobs, while EU leaders agreed to conduct another summit on assigning the bloc's top positions on June 30th. (Newswires)

Italian Deputy PM Salvini says he is ready to quit if the government cannot cut taxes for EUR 10bln, according to Corriere Della Sera. (Newswires)

FX

DXY remained soft and traded around the 96.50 level as it resumed the fall-out from the dovish FOMC. The weakness in the greenback continued to support its transatlantic counterparts in which EUR/USD just about reclaimed the 1.1300 level where there is a large option expiry of EUR 2.4bln for today’s New York cut. GBP/USD also marginally extended above 1.2700 to recoup most the losses from the somewhat dovish rhetoric from the BoE, while the latest round of the Conservative leadership vote provided no help for the currency as hardcore Brexiteer Boris Johnson maintained a considerable lead over Jeremy Hunt as they prepare to square off in a final 2-way runoff involving up to 160,000 Conservative Party members next month. USD/JPY remained on the backfoot due to the USD-woes and eyed a test of the 107.00 level to the downside with inline CPI data failing to spur price action and antipodeans were slightly firmer as they benefitted from the upside in commodities and China currency strength. 

COMMODITIES

Commodities were mixed overnight with a mild pullback seen in WTI crude futures following the prior day’s considerable gains, in which prices rallied nearly 6% to briefly above USD 57.00/bbl due to a weaker greenback and heightened geopolitical tensions surrounding Iran. Elsewhere, gold extended on its post-FOMC rally with the gains exacerbated as the precious metal broke above USD 1400/oz for the first time since September 2013, while copper traded sideways as the risk momentum stalled in the region.

 

CME raised NYMEX Crude Oil August futures margins by 5.8% to USD 3650/contract and raised NY Harbor July Heating Oil futures margins by 4% to USD 3925/contract, while it also increased June COMEX 100 Gold futures margins by 8.8% to USD 3700/contract. (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS

 

US President Trump answered "you'll soon find out" when asked if the US will strike Iran. However, President Trump later added that he does not feel like his administration is pushing him toward conflict and in some cases it’s the opposite, while he suggested the drone shooter could have been someone who was "loose and stupid". (Newswires/Twitter)

US President Trump reportedly pulled back from launching attacks on Iran hours after approving strikes on a handful of targets including radar and missile batteries, while an official noted that planes were in the air and ships were in position but no missiles had been fired when the word came to stand down. (New York Times)

Several top US House Republicans said there must be a measured response to Iran actions, although there were separate comments from US House Speaker Pelosi that the US needs to do everything in its power to de-escalate situation with Iran. (Newswires)

Iran Foreign Minister Zarif alleged that the US wages economic terrorism on Iran and stated we don't seek war, but will zealously defend our skies, land and waters. There were also comments from Iran's UN Ambassador that the US unmanned drone entered Iranian airspace despite repeated radio warnings in a blatant violation of international law. (Newswires)

Iranian-backed Houthi's launched large-scale drone attacks on UAVs and military targets at Saudi's Jizan Airport, although Saudi air defences were said to have intercepted a Houthi drone strike in Jizan. In other news, Saudi Arabia warned there will be a very strong reaction if the Strait of Hormuz is ever closed by Iran. (Newswires/ELINT News)

EU’s Juncker commented that what Turkey is doing in territorial waters of Cyprus is unacceptable and that proposals against Turkey over the drilling will not be soft. (Newswires)

 

US

 

The T-plex continued to trade higher on Thursday, sending yields even lower, in the wake of a now non-patient Fed with an eye for rate cuts. The Fed-sensitive front end of the curve saw the most bidding seeing the 2-year yield drop c. 3bps at settlement. The curve itself saw some modest flattening where the 2s/10s contracted by c. 2bps. The US also sold USD 15bln in 5-year TIPS on Thursday at a high yield of 0.152%, with a chunky indirects takedown (75.73%), a B/C of 2.55x, and tailing by 0.2bps. US T-note futures (U9) settled 6+ ticks higher at 128-02.

US President Trump said Fed chair Powell will eventually "do what is right". In other news, President Trump also commented that US and Canada have come a long way on the USMCA agreement and that he hopes for bipartisan support, while reports also noted that US President Trump and Canadian PM Trudeau instructed officials to develop a joint action plan for collaborating on critical minerals. (Newswires)

PRE-MARKET CHINESE  STOCK NEWS: CLP (2 HK) may report a loss for H1 due to a decline of as much as HD 7bln in goodwill value of its Australia unit
content:
AnXin Trust & Investment (600816 CH) - A 5.6% stake in the Co. owned by its controlling shareholder was frozen. (Newswires)

China CITIC Bank (998 HK) - Co. suspends service at Citic Tower Branch in Hong Kong due to protests. (Newswires)

China Railway Group (390 HK) - Co. announces retirement of Chairman Li and that it won bids for CNY 16.9bln of projects. (Newswires) CLP (2 HK) - Co. may report a loss for H1 due to a decline of as much as HKD 7bln in goodwill value of its Australia unit. (SCMP)

Evergrande Real Estate (3333 HK) - Evergrande Group to acquire 2.2bln shares in Shengjing Bank for CNY 13.2bln. (Newswires)

Protests - Hong Kong government headquarters will be temporarily shut today as university student groups called for a rally to show discontent the extradition law wasn’t fully withdrawn by their set deadline, while they also demand all charges against those arrested during last week’s protests are dropped. (Newswires)

Other News - NBS report notes how municipal government officials pressure industrial firms to falsify revenues, depreciation of fixed assets, payroll and operating profits to inflate local economic results. (Newswires)

Trade

US and China negotiating teams could meet as soon as Tuesday. (SCMP)

CBIRC said the effect of US tariffs in China's economy will be very limited. (Newswires)

A senior administration official said the White House is not looking for a big breakthrough deal when Trump meets with Xi at the G-20 in Japan, according to Politico's Morning Money. (Politico)

China Global Times Editor made retaliatory comments to US Senator Rubio in which he alleged that Rubio keeps attaching labels to China as well as poisoning the perception of Chinese and American society towards each other. (Twitter)

China-EU investment access talks went better than expected and were “deeper than normal”, while the parties agreed to hold further meetings each month from July to speed up the process, according to diplomatic sources. Furthermore, reports also noted that China signed significant deals with Britain as it shores up alliances during the trade dispute with US. (Newswires/SCMP)
